So through the running of the copper like at different rotations different temperatures different uh bicarbonate concentrations we have started to break down uh those paths right and it it it's mind-boggling that all these things were already explained in the 70s. utterance: Charles McGrory: I do but but I I'm I get concerned about benchmarking for CO2. So, you know, CO2, especially CO2 reduction and especially electrochemical CO2 reduction, and I will say just as an aside, I think it's worth discussing whether electrochemical CO2 reduction is actually, I mean, I'm funded like all my work from it, so yeah, let's keep doing it, but is it really the most reasonable way of CO2 conversion? But moving away from that and assuming that it's great, you know, the problem that I see is that it's becoming saturated, CO2 reduction is being saturated with groups that publish and say, I have a new catalyst, it's the best ever, here it is. And benchmarking gets away from some of that, but what we saw when we did HER and OER benchmarking is everyone just tweaked their system to meet the new benchmarks and they basically, I mean, we got lots of high surface area nickel foam supported OER catalysts that of course have high activity per geometric area, but then it took a back seat to, I mean, sort of the mechanistic studies took a back seat to that because if you didn't meet certain performance metrics, you couldn't get published. And so there would be no way for you to think about, well this catalyst didn't work as well, here's why it didn't work as well, going back to some of the failure modes. That sort of fell away and I think it really hurt the OER community for several years because there were just so many papers about, well we have the best catalyst, look, it's 200 millivolt overpotential, it's 150 millivolt overpotential based on basically fake metrics because they gamed the system.

utterance: Lauren Wagner: Okay, great. Let's kick things off. Thanks, everyone, for joining. Today, we're going to brainstorm some novel approaches to accelerating drug discovery using AI, specifically for neurodegenerative diseases. Ben, I know you had some initial thoughts on leveraging genomic data. Do you want to start?

annotations.process management: The speaker is managing the meeting flow by starting the discussion and setting the agenda.
annotations.clarify goal: The speaker clearly states the goal of the meeting, which is to brainstorm novel approaches to accelerating drug discovery using AI for neurodegenerative diseases.
annotations.encourage participation: The speaker invites Ben to contribute by asking him to share his initial thoughts on leveraging genomic data.

utterance: Ben Carter: Yeah, thanks, Lauren. I was thinking we could develop a predictive model that integrates multi-omics data—genomics, proteomics, transcriptomics—to identify novel drug targets. The key challenge is the heterogeneity of the data. But if we use a graph neural network approach, we could model the complex biological interactions and potentially uncover pathways that traditional methods might miss.

annotations.propose new idea: Ben Carter introduces a new idea for developing a predictive model that integrates multi-omics data to identify novel drug targets.
annotations.develop idea: He elaborates on the idea by discussing the key challenge (heterogeneity of the data) and a potential solution (using a graph neural network approach).

utterance: Chloe Davis: I love that, Ben. The GNN approach is powerful. To build on that, what if we also incorporate patient data from electronic health records? We could add another layer to the model, linking molecular data to clinical phenotypes. This could help us not just find targets, but also stratify patient populations for clinical trials. We'd need to be careful with data privacy, of course, but the potential is huge.

annotations.supportive response: Chloe Davis expresses agreement and appreciation for Ben's idea.
annotations.develop idea: Chloe Davis expands on Ben's idea by suggesting the incorporation of patient data from electronic health records.

utterance: Lauren Wagner: That's a fantastic point, Chloe. Patient stratification is critical.

annotations.supportive response: The speaker is expressing agreement and validation for Chloe's point about incorporating patient data from electronic health records into their predictive model, emphasizing the importance of patient stratification.

utterance: David Chen: I agree, this is a promising direction. My main concern would be the computational cost and the interpretability of the GNN model. These can become black boxes. Maybe we could integrate a SHAP or LIME framework to help explain the model's predictions. That way, we can validate the biological relevance of the identified targets and pathways, making our findings more trustworthy for the bench scientists.

annotations.supportive response: The speaker agrees with the direction proposed.
annotations.critical response: The speaker raises concerns about the computational cost and interpretability of the GNN model.
annotations.offer feedback: The speaker suggests integrating a SHAP or LIME framework to address concerns.

utterance: Lauren Wagner: Excellent point on interpretability, David. That's crucial. Okay, this is a great start. We have a core idea: a multi-modal GNN with EHR data, plus an interpretability layer. I'm going to share my screen and start mapping this out on a whiteboard.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Lauren Wagner acknowledges David's point about interpretability.
annotations.summarize conversation: Lauren Wagner summarizes the core idea discussed so far.
